Prompt: My husband works a lot which really helps our family. The problem is he never wants to go anywhere with my children and me. When he gets home from work, he’s highly irritable and often goes around the house criticizing me for practically everything. Cleaning, watching the kids, what I did or didn’t do during the day, Ext. Most every time I talk with him, he has something negative to say about me. Something I didn’t do right. This is really starting to wear on me. My Self Esteem is pretty bad and this makes it worse. I also get very anxious when I know he’s coming home soon, because I know it is going to be constant critiques. Also, when I ask him if he wants to go someplace with me and the kids, he never wants to and gets upset about it. I get in a bad mood too and he ends up leaving. In which doesn’t make any sense because he said he didn’t want to go anywhere. I have told him how much these things bother me. Every time, he turns around and says what bother him. Nothing gets resolved. I work from home and it’s difficult because I am also watching the kids. He doesn’t like anyone else watching the kids so I try to the majority of the time, unless I have somewhere important to go to. We used to be a lot different. We would go out to dinner, shopping, ext. We would watch TV together and he really didn’t critique me all too much. He used to say good things about me in which he doesn’t say anymore. For example, he used to call me “pretty girl”. He has not said that for awhile now. We have also went through some crap that hurt our relationship. I wasn’t very mature when we started dating so I made some poor decisions that I would never do presently. I’d love to know what changed our relationship so much? Is he acting like this for revenge or because he’s not happy? I can honestly say I’m miserable when I’m around him. I cannot say I’m overall miserable because I do enjoy spending time with my children. My underneath layer is hurt, badly. I feel like my feelings don’t matter. I don’t know when and if to call it quits. We have been married for 6 years and I don’t give up easily. I do love him but I wish he was how he was when we got married. He actually cared and SHOWED me how much he loved me.
Response:
This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "Most every time I talk with him, he has something negative to say about me... This is really starting to wear on me." The speaker is basing their feelings of inadequacy on her husband's criticisms, rather than objectively evaluating the situation. 
* **Mental Filter:**  The speaker focuses solely on the negative aspects of her husband's behavior (criticism, lack of desire to go out) and doesn't mention any potential positive qualities he might have.
* **Should Statements:** "He should want to spend time with us," implies an expectation that her husband *should* behave a certain way, leading to disappointment when those expectations aren't met.
* **Overgeneralization:**  "Something I didn’t do right." This statement suggests the speaker believes she is constantly making mistakes, generalizing from isolated incidents.
* **Mind Reading:** "I also get very anxious when I know he’s coming home soon, because I know it is going to be constant critiques." The speaker assumes her husband will criticize her without any concrete evidence.

* **Fortune-telling:** "I don’t know when and if to call it quits." This statement reflects a pessimistic prediction about the future of the relationship.
* **Magnification:**  "My underneath layer is hurt, badly. I feel like my feelings don’t matter." The speaker exaggerates the impact of her husband's behavior on her self-worth.

* **Personalization:** "I have told him how much these things bother me. Every time, he turns around and says what bothers him. Nothing gets resolved." The speaker blames herself for the lack of resolution in their arguments, rather than acknowledging that communication is a two-way street.

It's important to note that this analysis focuses solely on the cognitive distortions present in the anecdote. It doesn't address the underlying issues within the relationship or offer solutions.

Prompt: I have 4 “versions” of myself. The main one (me) is the artistic one and sees everything in a positive light but can get depressed easily. The second main is Jake who is logical and sees everything more realistically but can get angry easier than the rest of us and is the strongest. The third version is Jack who is a over confident person who has no emotions for others and gets things he wants for the body’s benefit. The fourth one jakey is the happiest out of all of us and is very careless about the body. jakey sees things as “life is short so why not” type of attitude.jakey comes out in a very happy scene or when I get into a deep depressed state. We are all aware of each other and we all share the same memories. They started to exist after an overwhelming event of getting out of a bad relationship, going home to angry parents, and going to school was hell. I was 13 at the time and I kept my sadness inside because I didn’t want to worry my parents even more. I have a history of suicidal actions, and self-hurting actions. There are times where we all fight like siblings but nothing too harsh. They don’t look different from me however they act a lot different from me. I hope this make sense. Its not multiple personality because they look like me but they act very different from me (hence they are called versions) However, I know that it’s not nothing. I’ve decided to accept them and let them have full control of the body for one day throughout the week. Please tell me if this is a mistake or if there is something better I should do. Thank you for your time.
Response:
This anecdote presents several potential cognitive distortions. Here's a breakdown:

* **Emotional Reasoning:**  The description of the different "versions" seems heavily influenced by emotions. For example, the emergence of Jakey in happy or depressed states suggests an emotional trigger rather than a logical reason for their appearance.

* **Overgeneralization:** The anecdote mentions a history of suicidal and self-hurting actions. While these are serious concerns, attributing them solely to the overwhelming event at 13 might be an overgeneralization. Other factors could be contributing.

* **Labeling:**  The use of labels like "artistic," "logical," "overconfident," and "happiest" for each version can contribute to rigid thinking patterns and potentially reinforce unhelpful stereotypes.

* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** Allowing the different versions full control of the body for a day suggests an all-or-nothing approach. Is there a middle ground where they could collaborate or have more nuanced influence?

**Is this a mistake?**

It's impossible to say definitively whether allowing the "versions" full control is a mistake without further understanding and professional evaluation. 

**Here are some things to consider:**


* **Safety:** The history of suicidal and self-hurting actions raises serious concerns about safety. Allowing versions with potentially impulsive tendencies control could be risky.
* **Professional Help:** Seeking help from a mental health professional is crucial. They can provide a safe space to explore these experiences, identify underlying issues, and develop healthier coping mechanisms.

**Potential Alternatives:**

Instead of full control, consider exploring:

* **Communication and Collaboration:** Encourage the versions to communicate and work together towards shared goals.
* **Mindfulness Practices:** Techniques like meditation can help increase self-awareness and manage emotional fluctuations.
* **Therapy:** Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) can be effective in addressing cognitive distortions and developing healthier thinking patterns.



Remember, you're not alone. Seeking professional support is a sign of strength and can lead to a more fulfilling and balanced life.

Prompt: My husband’s uncle has great financial means however spends extremely little money on entertainment. He showed up unannounced for years often at supper hour and whenever he liked. After his girlfriend broke up with him his intrusions worsened. We repeatedly asked him to call before he came, but he would show up anyway and say “If you are busy I just go.” If we say we are busy he argues. Visits are often and prolonged. Finally, after waking us up one morning I firmly told him that he was asked to call and repeatedly violates our request. His first response was “You don’t like me.” I am also sick with Lupus and when this first big argument came I was caring for several children. He didn’t come unannounced nor even when invited for about 6 months and then out of the blue he started again. Then came the argument followed by absence then another 6 months all would start again. This cycle has been going on for about 5 years now. My husband and I explained why we needed him to call and he nodded his head as though he understood. After these talks I made sure to invite him over so that he would know he would be able to visit. His response is usually the same. “I may come, not sure what I am doing yet.” That ends up tying up our night as we don’t know if he is coming or not. If we invite others to play cards we may not be able to if he just shows up. Hubby feels guilty telling him that we are not up for company. It is badly straining our marriage as I can’t even rely on having a peaceful night. Hubby is stressed because he doesn’t want him doing it either but would put up with it if I didn’t complain. He also is extremely rude to us and other guests. He says and does mean things when he perceives an injustice towards him. Everything mean thing he does (which is often) seems to be calculated to send a message. The last 7 out of 8 invites we gave he caused issues. A pharmacist friend of mine told me to read “Controlling People” and I was shocked at how much scenarios in the book resembled this relative. How can I help my husband not feel guilty about insisting his uncle respect boundaries? My husband tries, then his uncles manipulates him and my husband yells at me as to why he can’t come over when he wants. (From Canada)
Response:
This anecdote exhibits several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** The writer feels frustrated and angry with the uncle's behavior, leading her to believe that his actions are intentionally malicious ("Everything mean thing he does... seems to be calculated to send a message.")  
* **Overgeneralization:** The writer concludes that "the last 7 out of 8 invites we gave he caused issues," suggesting a pattern based on a limited sample.
* **Should Statements:** The writer feels her husband "should" insist on boundaries and not feel guilty about it. This implies an expectation for how others should behave rather than accepting their individual choices and limitations.
* **Mind Reading:**  The writer assumes the uncle's intentions ("You don’t like me.") without concrete evidence, projecting her own feelings onto him.

* **Personalization:** The writer takes responsibility for the situation, feeling she needs to "help" her husband not feel guilty. While empathy is important, it's crucial to recognize that the uncle's behavior is ultimately his own responsibility.


It's clear that this situation is causing significant stress and strain on the writer's marriage. Addressing these cognitive distortions could help her approach the problem more constructively.

This anecdote exhibits several cognitive distortions that suggest a need for professional help:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "My real childhood was an absolute horror, and I don’t understand what is happening to me." The individual is basing their understanding of their current situation solely on the intense negative emotions they are experiencing.

**It is crucial that this individual seeks professional help from a therapist or psychiatrist experienced in treating trauma.** They may be experiencing complex post-traumatic stress disorder (C-PTSD) or dissociative identity disorder (DID).  A mental health professional can provide the necessary support and guidance to process their trauma, develop healthy coping mechanisms, and work towards healing.

This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "I can’t leave him alone at my apartment in fear he will do something and get me evicted, or worse." The speaker is making a decision (not leaving their father alone) based on fear rather than logical assessment of the situation.

* **Should Statements:**  "My father needs help that I can’t give him..." This implies a "should" – the speaker feels they *should* be able to provide help, leading to feelings of guilt and inadequacy.

* **Overgeneralization:** "This has been going on for years." While it's true this is a recurring issue, phrasing it as "always" can lead to hopelessness and a sense that there's no solution.

* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:**  The speaker sees sending their father back onto the street as the only alternative to keeping him at home, ignoring potential middle ground solutions like temporary shelters or respite care.


Let me know if you'd like to explore any of these distortions in more depth, or brainstorm possible resources and strategies for the speaker.

Prompt: I am a co-facilitator (pro bono, unlicensed) for a men’s DV group (court-mandated) at a non-profit. The leader is a therapist who also has a private practice. In group one of the men mentioned fear of losing his probation for something he didn’t do and being imprisoned for years at an upcoming hearing. He didn’t return to the group after the hearing. She discovered he indeed had been jailed with another hearing soon to determine whether he will be imprisoned. He’s made enormous progress, despite a terrible childhood and adverse family dynamics, he has a good heart and reaches out to other group members, attends a drug-tested substance abusers group three times a week, and has focused on becoming a father again to his children (they were not the recipients of his abuse). But he’s also expressed suicidal thoughts in the past in the context of never wanting to go back to prison, and he’s become worn out and depressed in dealing with The System (frequent court hearings, probation officers, in-laws, etc. – you can imagine), and we’re deeply concerned about his mental health. He’s received no visitors. LA County is under a DOJ consent agreement to improve its mental health resources, but there have been numerous suicides nonetheless. The therapist is considering visiting the client in jail to check on his health and give him moral support, to let him know someone cares. But she and the non-profit center are conflicted about ethics and boundaries and dual relationships – she says this issue was never discussed in school or workshops, and the non-profit doesn’t even have a policy because this issue has never arisen before. I think it’s because the people setting boundaries aren’t the kind of people who go to jail very often. A large proportion of the country’s 2 million prisoners have some degree of mental illness and get almost no care. He hasn’t called — he’s expressed a sense of unworthiness that might keep him from calling. I don’t think this is the usual ethics and boundaries issue, and I think in these circumstances the benefit for man’s mental health and maybe even his life far outweighs the boundary risk. What do you think? It seems a Catch-22, but shouldn’t be, given the problem of mental illness in prisons.
Response:
This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** The narrator believes that because they feel deeply concerned for the man's well-being, visiting him in jail must be the right thing to do. They are basing their decision on emotion rather than carefully considering all ethical and practical implications. 
* **Should Statements:**  The narrator expresses a belief that "the benefit for the man’s mental health and maybe even his life far outweighs the boundary risk." This implies a "should" statement – that therapists *should* prioritize client well-being above all else, even when it conflicts with established ethical guidelines.
* **Mind Reading:** The narrator assumes the man hasn't called because he feels unworthy. While this might be true, there could be other reasons for his silence (lack of access to phones, fear of repercussions, etc.).

**Other potential distortions**:

* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** The narrator frames the situation as a Catch-22, suggesting there are only two extreme options: strict adherence to boundaries or risking everything for the client. This overlooks potential compromises or alternative solutions.
* **Magnification:** The narrator highlights the severity of the man's situation (potential suicide, lack of visitors) and the dire consequences of inaction (prison suicides), potentially exaggerating the risk involved in not visiting him.

It's important to note that these are just potential distortions based on the limited information provided. A thorough ethical analysis would require considering all relevant factors and consulting with experienced professionals.

Prompt: I am a 15 year old male from Kansas that has lived a normal life except for the fact that I can’t remember the last time I was happy. There is this girl that I have been “friends” with my whole life and I started being in love with her before I even knew what love was. Everyone keeps telling me that what I am going through is completely normal and lots of people go through it, I know this but the fact remains that I have been depressed for 5 years now because I know that she couldn’t care less about me. She calls me her friend but she told me she doesn’t want me in her life. I have recently told a handful of people how I feel and I wish I could take back every word I said. I told my best friend who now thinks I am ridiculous, I told my parents who repetitively tell me to just move on, and I told the love of my life how I feel about her and she said she couldn’t care less. This has ruined my friendship, my family, and my whole life. I am a good student that makes straight A’s but I can’t focus at school because I am up till 2:00 am crying myself to sleep. I don’t eat as much, I can’t sleep, and I have randomly placed emotional breakdowns. I love my parents but I don’t think they can help, I can’t even tell them all of how I feel because I know it will hurt them too much. Just about a year ago I contemplated taking my own life, I have moved pass this and will never think that way again but I am a Christian and I still find myself praying every night for death. I don’t know what to do or where to turn. I feel worthless and unwanted, please help.
Response:
This anecdote exhibits several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "Everyone keeps telling me that what I am going through is completely normal... but the fact remains that I have been depressed for 5 years..." He's letting his feelings of despair dictate his reality, dismissing logical reassurance.
* **Overgeneralization:**  "This has ruined my friendship, my family, and my whole life." One unrequited love is being catastrophized to encompass all aspects of his existence.
* **Mental Filter:** He focuses solely on the negative (rejection, pain) and ignores potential positives (good grades, supportive parents who, though not fully understanding, still care).
* **Should Statements:** "I should just move on." This implies an unrealistic expectation of himself to instantly overcome complex emotions.
* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:**  "She couldn’t care less about me" and "I am a good student that makes straight A's but I can’t focus at school..." He views situations in extremes – either complete indifference or utter failure.
* **Mind Reading:** "I don’t think they can help, I can’t even tell them all of how I feel because I know it will hurt them too much." He assumes his parents' reaction without directly communicating with them.
* **Fortune-Telling:** "I still find myself praying every night for death." This predicts a perpetually negative future outcome.

**Magnification** and **Personalization** are also present, though less explicitly: he exaggerates the impact of the rejection and feels personally responsible for his unhappiness.


It's crucial to emphasize that this young man is experiencing significant emotional distress and needs professional help. These cognitive distortions are common symptoms of depression and anxiety, and a therapist can help him develop healthier coping mechanisms.

Prompt: My father and step-mother were seeing a counselor for marital issues (imago therapy–I’m not sure what that means). She tells him he’s incapable of empathizing with people, then scoffs at him for crying–“that’s not empathy. You’re just being sentimental.” (I cry every time I I think about it,) My father’s friends and family have pulled away from him, because my step-mother makes them uncomfortable. At times it feels surreal, like I’m living in a case study from that book by R. Hare (the  psychopathy checklist). My father has an eccentric personality and mild social anxiety (he doesn’t like large gatherings, but he manages). Those are the only Aspergers traits he exhibits. My father’s friends and family are very concerned about him, and I can’t help feeling like his therapist gave my step-mother the weapon she’s using to pummel my father. I don’t know what to do. Are there guidelines about offering diagnoses in a family therapy setting? I feel like I’m watching a train wreck. My father agrees with me that something is wrong, but he won’t walk away, even when my step-mother leaves him for weeks at a time, and tells him she loves someone else. What can I do. Am I making a scapegoat of their therapist? It just feels like she behaved recklessly and at the expense of my father. (age 38, from US)
Response:
This anecdote exhibits several cognitive distortions:

* **Mental Filter:** The writer focuses solely on the negative aspects of the stepmother's behavior (manipulation, abuse, broadcasting the diagnosis) while seemingly overlooking any potential positive traits she might have.
* **Emotional Reasoning:**  The writer states "I cry every time I think about it," indicating that their strong emotional response is influencing their perception of the situation. They feel like they are "watching a train wreck" which suggests distress-driven thinking rather than objective analysis.
* **Should Statements:** The writer expresses frustration with the father's inaction: "he won’t walk away, even when my step-mother leaves him for weeks at a time," implying that he *should* leave the relationship.
* **Labeling:** The writer labels the stepmother as manipulative and abusive, and compares her behavior to psychopathy. They also label the therapist's actions as "reckless."

* **Overgeneralization**: While it's understandable to be upset about the situation, statements like "My father’s friends and family have pulled away from him" generalize the impact of the stepmother's actions without accounting for other potential factors.

**It's important to note:**

While these cognitive distortions are present, it's crucial to approach this situation with empathy and understanding. The writer is clearly distressed by what they perceive as their father's mistreatment. 


The anecdote raises ethical questions about the therapist's conduct in disclosing a potential diagnosis in a family setting without proper individual assessment and consent. It highlights the complexities of family dynamics and the potential harm that can arise from miscommunication and misuse of information.

Prompt: I am 23 years old, and a female. I have never been in a romantic, sexual relationship with any man (although I have kissed many and really enjoyed it). I have only ever wanted to be in an emotional intimate relationship with a man. However, I feel aroused when I watch two women having sex, which scares and confuses me. Over the last week I have this screaming thought in my head that I am gay, and I can’t seem to get rid of it no matter how hard I try. However the thought of being romantically attached and in a relationship with a women repulses me and makes me sick. I feel extreme anxiety, and it has severely changed my sleeping and eating patterns. I am up all night wondering if I am gay as well as wondering if I will ever have any romantic attachment with a man. As soon as I try and convince myself that I am straight, I panic and feel like I’m lying to myself, and tell myself that I am deep in denial. Every time I go out, I am scared that I will see a girl and fall in love with her and lose all my interest in men, which scares me even more. I came across information about HOCD, and immediately identified with of all the emotional and physical experiences that other people went through, which made me feel a bit more calm. But now I have started to convince myself that what I identified with when I read HOCD was a lie and that deep down I am a closeted gay (even though I know that’s not true). I have spoken to my mother and a few of my friends about how I am feeling which helps me feel less stressed but five minutes later to an hour I convince myself that all I have said was a lie and I am deep in denial, which makes me more depressed.  I don’t know what I am feeling and it scares the hell out of me. I feel like I have lost my identity. I was wondering if there was any techniques that I could use to make me feel calm and think rationally. I would love to see a therapist but I have too many other expenses in my life so I can’t afford it. Please help me. I want to feel the way I used to, which was excited at the prospect of meeting a man and falling completely in love with them, and not depressed and repulsed by the thought of falling in love with a woman. (age 23, South Africa)
Response:
This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "I feel aroused when I watch two women having sex, which scares and confuses me... As soon as I try and convince myself that I am straight, I panic and feel like I’m lying to myself..." The individual is basing their understanding of their sexual orientation solely on feelings of arousal, rather than considering other factors or a broader context.

* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** "Every time I go out, I am scared that I will see a girl and fall in love with her and lose all my interest in men, which scares me even more."  This demonstrates a black-and-white thought pattern where the individual believes there's no middle ground - either they are completely straight or completely gay.

* **Should Statements:** "I have never had, nor am I a crushing on a girl. I have only ever wanted to be in an emotional intimate relationship with a man."  There's an implied "should" here – the individual feels there's something wrong with experiencing arousal towards same-sex content despite their desire for heterosexual relationships.

* **Mind Reading:** "...I convince myself that all I have said was a lie and I am deep in denial..." The individual is assuming they are deceiving themselves and others without any concrete evidence.

* **Fortune-telling:** "I feel like I have lost my identity." This statement predicts a negative and permanent outcome based on current feelings of confusion and anxiety.


It's important to note that these distortions are common when someone is struggling with their sexual identity. It's crucial for the individual to seek support from trusted friends, family, or online communities. While therapy is ideal, there are also self-help resources available that can help challenge these distorted thoughts and promote self-acceptance.

This anecdote exhibits several cognitive distortions:

* **Overgeneralization:**  The statement "This anxiety if change has always followed me" generalizes a specific pattern to encompass the entire lifespan, potentially ignoring instances where they adapted well to change.

* **Should Statements:**  Implicitly feeling there "shouldn't" be any anxiety about change, leading to self-criticism.



It's important to note that identifying cognitive distortions is not about labeling someone as "wrong." It's a tool for understanding thought patterns that may contribute to distress and exploring more balanced perspectives.

**Additional Considerations:**

* **Fortune-telling:**  The belief that they will "do the wrong thing" and "say something wrong" suggests predicting a negative outcome without evidence.

**It's important to note:** This is just an analysis based on a limited text sample. A proper diagnosis of cognitive distortions would require a comprehensive evaluation by a mental health professional.

Prompt: I’m a student receiving my Masters degree. Within the past two years I’ve felt my body and mind change significantly in many ways. I then push everything aside and get nothing done. My habits of cleanliness such as my apartment have declined because I refuse to motivate myself to clean. I’ll find myself in the kitchen then in the bedroom for some reason the randomly in the bathroom, ultimately accomplishing nothing. I get distracted by TV a lot and it impedes my homework. I also feel pressured on what to do when I finish my masters and feel like I’m too lackadaisical to even search for jobs. My relationship with my boyfriend is also affected by this in that I’ll freak out on him, refuse sex, and find him at the mercy of which high or low I’ll be on. I’ll also find myself drinking and smoking cigarettes more often to avoid doing work or tasks. I feel like I have adult ADD due to these symptoms and have spoken with my mother, who revealed she believes she has it as well but was never properly diagnosed. I would like to know what to do and what would happen if I see a psychiatrist.
Response:
This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:**  "I feel extremely anxious... I then push everything aside and get nothing done." The student is letting their feelings of anxiety dictate their actions, rather than logically assessing the situation.

* **Overgeneralization:** "I'll find myself in the kitchen then in the bedroom for some reason the randomly in the bathroom, ultimately accomplishing nothing." This suggests a pattern of unproductive behavior, but it might be an overgeneralization based on a limited number of instances.

* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:**  "I feel like I’m too lackadaisical to even search for jobs." This statement reflects a black-and-white thinking pattern – either they are completely motivated or utterly incapable. There's likely a spectrum of motivation and ability in between.

* **Should Statements:** "I also feel pressured on what to do when I finish my masters..." The student feels pressure about their future, implying they *should* have a clear plan by now.

* **Mental Filter:** Focusing primarily on the negative aspects (anxiety, procrastination, relationship issues) and not acknowledging potential positives (achieving a Master's degree, having a boyfriend).

* **Magnification:**  "I’ll freak out on him, refuse sex, and find him at the mercy of which high or low I’ll be on." The student is exaggerating the impact of their mood swings on their relationship.

* **Avoidance:** Turning to drinking and smoking as a way to escape responsibilities and anxiety.

**It's important to note:** While these distortions are present, it's crucial to avoid self-diagnosis.  The student should consult with a mental health professional for a proper evaluation. A psychiatrist can help determine if the symptoms align with Adult ADHD or another condition and recommend appropriate treatment options.

Prompt: I have battled with my idiosyncrasies since I was a little girl. I always thought I was merely particular, maybe slightly obsessive. * **Overgeneralization:** "I have certain ways every little thing needs to be done and I feel like the world is ending when those systems are disrupted." This suggests a pattern of catastrophizing minor inconveniences.
* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:**  The individual feels intense distress over things being out of order, suggesting a black-and-white view where anything less than perfect order is unacceptable.
* **Should Statements:** "I don’t want this sort of thing influencing the way my child learns to cope with emotions." This implies a belief that her reactions *should* be different and controlled.
* **Magnification:**  The individual experiences panic attacks over disorganization, exaggerating the severity of the situation.


**Possible Additional Considerations:**

* **Labeling:** Phrases like "severely socially apprehensive" and describing herself as having "idiosyncrasies" could be examples of labeling herself negatively.

It's important to remember that diagnosing cognitive distortions requires professional evaluation. This analysis is based solely on the provided anecdote.

It's important to remember that labeling cognitive distortions is just the first step. The individual would benefit from seeking professional help from a therapist specializing in trauma and intrusive thoughts. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) could be particularly helpful in addressing these distortions and developing coping mechanisms.

Prompt: Does it ever happen that panic attacks (and by extension, panic disorder) develop from another condition? I started having panic attacks about eight months ago with varying frequency and intensity. I’ve never had some of the most common complaints, like feelings of choking or having a heart attack. Mostly I get very dizzy and spacey, along with a panicked feeling of course. It’s sometimes hard to follow conversations or even keep my balance. I’ve also started having blurry vision (akin to nearsightedness) and sometimes cloudy vision. More recently I’ve been getting shaky too. It used to be a slight tremble at most, but now I occasionally have people ask me if I’m alright or comment that it’s not that cold out because I look like I’m shivering. This doesn’t necessarily happen during a panic attack either. Sometimes I’ll be laying in bed trying sleep or driving to work when it happens. I know these things can be symptoms of panic and are common side effects of medications, but they don’t seem to correlate with changes in dosage or starting/stopping a med. In addition, I’m just wondering (maybe even hoping) if it’s not uncommon for people to have panic attacks as a result of other underlying issues. I’m going back to get blood tests done soon (my gp has been on me about it for months, but it’s hard to find a day that I’m both off work and also feeling up to it). Last time I had them done everything was more or less normal, but that was over a year before all this started. I keep telling myself that there must be something else causing me to feel this way, because like I said, I don’t seem to experience panic attacks quite the same as most people. It’s also concerning that my prescribed benzodiazepine stops the panic, but a lot of the other symptoms persist (like the blurry vision, dizziness, and extreme fatigue despite it being the smallest dose). Is this something that happens with any kind of frequency? In truth, I’m sort of hoping there’s something else going on that is a little more… definitive, if that makes sense. Thanks.
Response:
This anecdote shows several cognitive distortions at play. Here's a breakdown:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "I keep telling myself that there must be something else causing me to feel this way..." The individual is basing their belief about an underlying cause solely on their feelings of unease and discomfort, rather than concrete evidence.
* **Mental Filter:**  The person focuses on the atypical nature of their panic attacks ("like I said, I don’t seem to experience panic attacks quite the same as most people") while potentially downplaying the severity of the symptoms they *do* experience.
* **Should Statements:** "It's also concerning that my prescribed benzodiazepine stops the panic, but a lot of the other symptoms persist..." There's an implied "should" here –  the medication *should* resolve all symptoms if it's addressing the root issue. This sets up unrealistic expectations and contributes to further anxiety.
* **Fortune-telling:**  "...Is this something that happens with any kind of frequency? In truth, I’m sort of hoping there’s something else going on that is a little more… definitive..." The individual is anticipating a specific outcome (finding a definitive underlying cause) based on their current feelings and limited information.

**It's important to note:** This analysis shouldn't be used for self-diagnosis. The individual should continue working with their GP and potentially seek referral to a mental health professional for a comprehensive evaluation and treatment plan.

I’d suggested people feel free to arrange additional impromptu events but said if someone were to do so please RSVP quickly either way otherwise no one will want to organize anything if no one responds. So I target activities that are ongoing so I have contact with the same people so friendships build slowly without initiating too early to be knocked back. * **Emotional Reasoning:** "I don’t get heard" leads to discouragement and a feeling of futility, implying that because the person feels unheard, it must be true.

* **Overgeneralization:**  Experiences with one colleague and difficulty getting included in social events are generalized into beliefs like "At work I don’t get taken seriously" and "I'm often not included."

* **Mental Filter:** The person focuses on instances where their communication was unsuccessful (ignored suggestions, lack of invitations) while potentially overlooking times when they were heard or included.

* **Should Statements:** There are implicit "shoulds" like "My manager should include me in planning meetings," and "People should RSVP promptly." This sets up unrealistic expectations and fuels disappointment.

* **Fortune-telling:** The fear that discussing concerns with the manager won't be productive is a prediction based on past experiences, assuming the future will mirror the past.

* **Magnification:**  The impact of last-minute cancellations is magnified, leading to feelings of discouragement and avoidance of initiating social events.


* **Personalization:** The person takes responsibility for not being included in social activities, believing they are somehow at fault ("I just don’t feel like continuing to try").

It's important to note that while these distortions are present, the individual also demonstrates positive qualities like self-awareness, a desire for connection, and efforts to improve communication skills. Recognizing these distortions is the first step towards challenging them and developing more balanced thought patterns.

* **Should Statements:** "My mother always say that [I want to help people as a surgeon]... but even though that is not my goal..." This implies an expectation that they *should* be motivated by altruism, even if they aren't.
* **Labeling:**  The individual labels themselves as potentially "wrong" and describes their actions with terms like "cold-blooded."

* **Mind Reading:**  "I fantasize about murdering or torturing people that has wronged me... but I won't do it cuz I will get a criminal record." This suggests an assumption that others would perceive them negatively for these fantasies, even though there's no evidence of this.

* **Magnification:** The individual exaggerates the impact of their actions (e.g., running away to "punish" parents) and seems to derive pleasure from causing distress to others.



**It is crucial to remember that this is just an analysis based on a short anecdote.**  A proper diagnosis would require a comprehensive evaluation by a mental health professional.

The individual's actions and thoughts are concerning and suggest the potential presence of personality disorders or other mental health issues. Seeking professional help is highly recommended.

* **Fortune-telling:**  "if I don't do well in the first one...I'm scared thinking about it." This predicts a negative outcome based on fear rather than realistic evaluation.
* **Magnification:** "This habit has reduced my productivity" The individual exaggerates the impact of their ADHD on their ability to study.

* **Personalization:**  "I feel guilty for betraying my parent’s faith in me." They take full responsibility for a situation influenced by both personal challenges and external factors.


**It's important to note:** This individual is struggling with significant anxiety related to academic pressure and their ADHD diagnosis. Prompt: Need help dealing with high conflict ex-wife of boyfriend. They share custody of 3 teens; divorced 7 years. Her solution was to take them to the shelter with his 14 year old son, telling him his father was forcing her to do it, that his father is selfish for not letting her leave the dogs “for just another few weeks.” My bf’s son, who is a “young” 14, is sad and angry at his father, which is typical of these scenarios. This isn’t, as you might imagine, just about the dogs – boundaries that are enforced are punished through the kids. I encourage him to keep strong boundaries and he does increasingly so. This anecdote exhibits several cognitive distortions:

He might be thinking "She's so unreasonable!" or "I'm doing everything right, why is she punishing me?" This leads him to believe her actions are inherently wrong because they *feel* wrong.

* **Overgeneralization:** The ex-wife's abandonment of dogs and stealing the EZ Pass could lead to overgeneralizations like "She's always going to be selfish and manipulative" or "I can never trust her."

* **Mental Filter:** The boyfriend is focusing on the negative aspects of his ex-wife's behavior (abandoning dogs, stealing, using the children) while potentially overlooking any positive interactions he might have with her.

* **Should Statements:** He might be thinking "She should be more responsible" or "My kids shouldn't have to go through this." These "should" statements set unrealistic expectations and lead to disappointment.

* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** The situation is complex, but the boyfriend may perceive it in black and white terms: either he completely caves to his ex-wife's demands or he is a bad father for enforcing boundaries.


* **Mind Reading:** He assumes his ex-wife is intentionally trying to punish him through the children. While this might be true, he doesn't have direct access to her thoughts and motivations.

* **Fortune-telling:** The boyfriend might worry that things will never get better, that his relationship with his kids will always be strained, and that his ex-wife will continue to manipulate them.

* **Magnification:** He is exaggerating the impact of his ex-wife's actions, leading to significant stress and physical illness.


**Personalization:** While he acknowledges his children are older and making their own choices, he might still feel personally responsible for their emotional well-being and blame himself for not being able to "fix" the situation.

 **Labeling:**  He labels his ex-wife as "selfish" and "manipulative," which reinforces negative thinking patterns and hinders finding constructive solutions.

* **Labeling:** "I’m not a huge fan of labels but wondering if it’s common for a therapist to tell you if they diagnosed you or not?" While not explicitly labeling themselves, the individual is concerned about receiving a label (APD) and struggles with the ambiguity.

* **Personalization:**  "My grandma forces me to literally pretend I'm not depressed... my father won’t acknowledge me..." The individual takes personal responsibility for their family's lack of understanding and support, suggesting they are somehow at fault for this situation.


**It is crucial to remember that these are just labels for thought patterns.** They do not define the individual or invalidate their experience. Recognizing these distortions can be a first step towards challenging them and seeking healthier coping mechanisms.

 **Most importantly:** This individual is in a very vulnerable and dangerous situation. It is imperative they seek help immediately.  

Here are some resources:

* **Crisis Text Line:** Text HOME to 741741

Between constant child support payments, conversations with the ex’s, his family’s connection with those ex-wives (since they still talk) I feel like we are never going to be able to move on with OUR lives and focus on starting our own family. I am tired of having to deal with all these ex’s and kids when all i want him to do is have him cut them out of his life completely or not talk to them and only talk with the kids. However, I know this is unfair. This has all DESTROYED us financially and is now putting stress on our own relationship. We also recently found out that his 16 year old daughter is having a baby so now there’s not just kids but grand-kids! This is all new to me as I was not brought up this way at all and am having trouble not being judgmental. What can I do to learn to accept his past and know that it will always be a part of our lives because I do love him and want to be with him. (From the USA)
Response:
This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Overgeneralization:**  "His past is not a past... therefore, his past is really part of our present and our future." This statement takes isolated instances (child support, conversations with exes) and generalizes them to define the entirety of their future. 
* **Should Statements:** "I want him to do is have him cut them out of his life completely or not talk to them and only talk with the kids."  This reflects a belief that her fiance *should* behave in a certain way, disregarding his own feelings and relationships.
* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:**  "We also recently found out that his 16 year old daughter is having a baby so now there’s not just kids but grand-kids!" This statement frames the situation as drastically negative (now grandkids!) without considering potential positives or nuances.
* **Mental Filter:** The narrator focuses solely on the negative aspects of her fiance's past relationships (financial strain, ex-wife interactions), neglecting any potential positive contributions these relationships might have had in his life.

**Possible Underlying Issues:**

* **Fear of Abandonment:**  The desire to cut off all contact with exes could stem from a fear that her fiancé will leave her for them.
* **Lack of Trust:** Difficulty accepting his past suggests underlying trust issues within the relationship.
* **Insecurity:** Comparing their situation to her own upbringing might highlight feelings of insecurity and inadequacy.



It's important for the narrator to work on identifying and challenging these cognitive distortions. Talking to a therapist could be beneficial in helping her develop healthier coping mechanisms and build a stronger, more secure relationship with her fiancé.

Prompt: From a teen in the U.S.: My parents argue a lot. My mom always complains to me about my dad. He’s an alright guy, but he is bipolar. Based on the anecdote provided, here are some potential labels that could apply:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** The teen seems to be drawing conclusions about their father's behavior solely based on their feelings ("He gets angry so fast for no reason"). They might not be considering other factors or perspectives.

* **Mental Filter:**  The teen focuses primarily on the negative aspects of their father's bipolar disorder (anger, destruction, abandonment) and doesn't mention any positive qualities he may possess. 

* **Magnification:** The incident where the father wrecked his room and left is being presented as a significant and recurring problem. While it was undoubtedly upsetting, the teen labeling it as something that "wasn't this bad (I think) when I was younger" suggests they might be exaggerating its frequency.

* **Personalization:** The teen states  "we always have to be careful around him." This implies they feel personally responsible for managing their father's moods and preventing outbursts, which can be a heavy burden for a teenager.



It's important to remember that these are just potential labels based on a short anecdote. A full understanding of the situation would require more context and information about the teen's overall thoughts and feelings.

Prompt: Hello! I would say I’m very normal, and I’m happy to be alive. I am still young so I haven’t had any traumatic experience throughout my life. It scares me, because I could never hurt my family or good friends, that makes me feel disgusted. Then I thought, a normal person would feel disgust for hurting anyone. So, am I normal?
Response:
This anecdote exhibits several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** The individual justifies their disturbing thoughts by stating they get a "better feeling" of comforting someone in need. This links their emotions (feeling good) to the validity of their thoughts (fantasizing about violence).
* **Overgeneralization:** They state "I could easily kill people," suggesting this is a universal truth about themselves based on limited evidence (their fantasies).

* **Mind Reading:** They assume "a normal person would feel disgust for hurting anyone" implying they know what is "normal" and project that onto others. 
* **Should Statements:** The individual expresses a desire to be "normal," suggesting they believe there's a right way to think and feel, imposing pressure on themselves.

**Important Note:** This anecdote reveals deeply troubling thoughts. It's crucial for this individual to seek professional help from a mental health professional. These thoughts are not typical and require careful evaluation and support.

Prompt: Hello! I’m a 13 year old girl and I’ve been struggling with bulimia for a year and a couple of months now. I’m at a perfectly healthy weight but want to lose 20 pounds. Any time I start dieting I cant handle the hunger, eat as much as I can and then puke in the bathroom. This has been happening everyday for the last 13-14 months but my weight hasn’t changed at all. There were days where I would puke like 5-6 times a day, but sometimes I would manage not to do it for days. (Which is really hard and a whole acheivment for me.) NOBODY knows about it and I haven’t talked to anybody about it. I feel stupid and ashamed of it. I also feel extreme anxiety and suffer panic attacks any time i have to attend a social event, only because I hate my body and I think everyone on the street is looking at me and saying “Oh my God she is so fat, look at her” and etc. Please help me, I want to stop doing that, I want to have a healthy lifestyle and a healthy mind. I feel great for admitting it to you but also awful for being so stupid for having it at such a young age. Please don’t think of me as a silly confused child, I really need help. I scored severe in the Bulimia nervosa quiz at your site, and I know it shouldn’t be taken as a diagnosis, but I’m really sick and tired of it. Give me an advise how to win over it alone, because there are no specialists or clinics where I live. Thank you!!! (age 13, from Bulgaria)
Response:
This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:**  "I hate my body and I think everyone on the street is looking at me and saying 'Oh my God she is so fat, look at her' ". This demonstrates believing feelings are facts.
* **Overgeneralization:** "Any time I start dieting I can't handle the hunger, eat as much as I can and then puke in the bathroom."  Drawing a sweeping conclusion about her ability to diet based on limited experiences. 
* **Mental Filter:** Focusing solely on the negative aspects (weight, purging) and not acknowledging any positive steps she's taken (managing not to purge for days).
* **Should Statements:** "I should be able to control my eating." Implying there is a "right" way to behave and feeling guilt when she doesn't meet that standard.
* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:**  Viewing her progress as a complete failure because her weight hasn't changed. There's no recognition of the effort involved.
* **Mind Reading:** Assuming everyone is judging her appearance negatively ("everyone on the street is looking at me and saying 'Oh my God she is so fat'"). 
* **Magnification:** Exaggerating the negative consequences of her eating habits ("I feel stupid and ashamed") and minimizing any positive aspects.

**Label: Severe Cognitive Distortions Related to Bulimia**


It's crucial for this young girl to receive professional help. While self-help strategies can be useful, bulimia is a serious eating disorder that requires expert guidance. Encourage her to reach out to trusted adults (parents, teachers) or online resources specializing in eating disorder support.

Prompt: I have been in a relationship with my best friend for five years. We are a great fit in all ways, but he frequently questions my integrity and his self-worth. Response:
This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Should Statements:**  "I should have gone to the cops," implies a belief that there was a "right" way to handle the situation, leading to self-blame.

* **Mental Filter:** She focuses heavily on her boyfriend's pain and distrust, while downplaying her own trauma and fear during the ordeal.

* **Personalization:**  She takes responsibility for her boyfriend's negative feelings ("he will only see his pain...when that was not my intention"). This ignores the complex factors contributing to his reaction. 

* **Fortune-telling:** "That [the event] will always be a stain on my relationship resume..." predicts a permanently negative outcome, ignoring the possibility of growth and healing.



It's important to note that these are just labels for thought patterns. They don't define her character or invalidate her experiences. Recognizing these distortions is the first step towards addressing them and potentially working towards forgiveness and a healthier relationship dynamic.

She's basing her conclusion about her boyfriend's love on her feelings and his action (taking her back), rather than objectively evaluating their relationship dynamics.

* **Mental Filter:** She focuses solely on the positive aspects of the other guy ("never fights," "talks to me with so much more respect," "makes me feel so much more loved") while ignoring potential negatives like his unreliability ("wouldn't stick around").
* **Overgeneralization:**  She concludes that the other guy makes her "so much happier" than her boyfriend based on limited interactions. 

* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** She frames her choices as an either/or situation: a boyfriend who loves her but is mean, or a guy who is sweet but won't commit. This ignores the possibility of finding someone who offers both love and respect.


Let me know if you'd like to explore any of these distortions further!

Prompt: Hello. My issue is about friendships and the aftermath of my toxicity. Let's look at why other labels might not fit as strongly:

* **Fortune-telling/Magnification:** The anecdote doesn't predict a future negative outcome or exaggerate the consequences of the cancellation.
* **Labeling:** While there might be underlying self-labeling ("toxic"), the excerpt focuses on interpreting X's behavior rather than labeling oneself or others. 


**Important Note:** Cognitive distortions are complex and often intertwined.  A longer conversation with the individual could reveal additional distortions at play.

* **Emotional Reasoning:**  The writer states that their brother gets "severely angry" when things don't go his way. This suggests they are attributing his anger solely to the external situation, rather than considering other potential factors contributing to his emotional state.

* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** The phrase "anything short of perfection as a failure" could apply here. If the brother is unable to cope with minor setbacks (internet being turned off, stick taken away), he may be experiencing this type of thinking, perceiving any deviation from his desired outcome as a complete failure.

* **Mind Reading:**  The writer mentions their mother's fear that "people will take him away." This suggests an assumption about others' perceptions and potential actions without concrete evidence.


It is important to note that diagnosing cognitive distortions requires professional expertise. This analysis is based on the information provided in the anecdote and should not be considered a formal diagnosis.

To keep my relationships okay sometimes I fake or overly act certain emotions I know I should have. I crave power and glory, to a point it should be a concern, yet sometimes lack motivation? I know I have experienced depression on many,many occasions. There’s things I’d like to do but I know I never could. I’ve been anticipating a major breakdown for about 8 from suppression, hiding, and faking. Ive had a great deal of tragedies, sexual abuse, abandonment, various suicides. I saved a friend once as a teen, I cut myself fairly bad, but I succeeded in taking the box cutter away after he cut his wrists, throat, and tried to stab his stomach. It plays out in my dreams like I remember, when I awake many things I’ve suppressed flood my head. Overall though the things I want to do, the things I find acceptable etc. thats what is scaring me, also that I can’t remember things.. I guess all of it. The thought of seeking actual help, I know what I feel isn’t normal, but I fear what will become of me or my family if I go and completely honest.

This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "I feel that way, so it must be true" is evident in statements like "I know what I feel isn't normal," and the fear of seeking help based on feeling scared rather than rational evaluation.
* **Overgeneralization:** Drawing sweeping conclusions like "I don't like people by any means" and "There’s things I’d like to do but I know I never could" without considering potential exceptions or nuances. 
* **Mental Filter:** Focusing solely on negative aspects like suicidal thoughts, self-harm, substance abuse, and lack of empathy while potentially downplaying any positive traits or experiences.
* **Should Statements:**  Expecting oneself to behave in a certain way ("I know I should have certain emotions").
* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** Viewing things in black and white terms, like craving "power and glory" and feeling "invincible" at times while also experiencing lack of motivation and fear.
* **Mind Reading:** Concluding that others are against them without concrete evidence ("I have a hard time knowing what's real or not, and if others are out to get me").
* **Fortune-Telling:** Predicting the worst possible outcome ("I fear what will become of me or my family if I go and completely honest").
* **Magnification:** Exaggerating the potential consequences of seeking help ("I anticipate a major breakdown") and the severity of their thoughts and impulses.

**It's crucial to remember that this is not a diagnosis.** This analysis is based on a single anecdote and should not be taken as professional medical advice. The individual clearly expresses significant distress and would benefit greatly from professional evaluation and support.

**Additionally:**

* **Magnification:** They exaggerate the impact of their doubts on their friends, believing they are "making life hard" for them.


It's important to note that these distortions are likely exacerbated by the individual's depression. Therapy could help them identify and challenge these thought patterns, leading to healthier relationship dynamics.

* **Should Statements:**  Phrases like "I expected the worst" and redirecting traffic imply a sense of obligation or "should" be doing something specific in this situation. You might be putting undue pressure on yourself to act a certain way.

It's important to remember that these are just possible interpretations. Only you can truly determine which distortions are most relevant to your experience.  

**Here are some suggestions for coping:**

* **Practice self-compassion:** Acknowledge that witnessing a traumatic event is incredibly difficult. It's okay to feel overwhelmed and angry. Be kind to yourself during this process.
* **Seek professional help:** If these thoughts continue to bother you or interfere with your daily life, consider talking to a therapist. They can provide tools and strategies for managing cognitive distortions and processing trauma.

* **Mind Reading:** "I’m kind of scared of him sometimes...he feels like killing people when they annoy him. and I’m always cautious around him now."  The narrator assumes her boyfriend's thoughts and intentions based on his behavior, without direct confirmation.
* **Fortune-telling:** "I’m scared on how he will react to that... I just need some advice. I have no idea what to do." The narrator predicts a negative outcome (her boyfriend's anger)  without knowing how the situation will actually unfold.

* **Magnification:** "he was like a completely different person. like he had no soul for a minute until he calmed down." The narrator exaggerates her boyfriend's reaction to blood, portraying it as a terrifying and unnatural shift in personality.
* **Personalization:** "I told his school...and the school told his mom. I’m scared on how he will react to that." The narrator feels personally responsible for the potential consequences of her actions, even though she acted with the intention of helping her boyfriend.


**It's crucial to recognize:** This anecdote depicts a dangerous and unhealthy relationship.  The narrator is exhibiting signs of codependency and enabling her boyfriend's harmful behavior. She needs support and guidance to prioritize her own safety and well-being.

Prompt: I broke up with a friend at school about a month ago and now have a strong hatred towards him. Any recommendations to help me would be fantastic.

This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:**  "Since then I have sometimes had surges of energy and hatred during which I think about killing him." The individual is acting on their intense feelings of hatred, believing those feelings are justified and necessitate action.

* **Magnification:** "Basically i’m worried that if I see him in real life I will lash out at him." The potential consequence (lashing out) is being exaggerated and catastrophized.

* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:**  "have only really talked to one of my friends and seem to have dug a hole I cant get out of." This suggests an extreme view - either they are completely socially isolated or perfectly fine. There's no room for nuance in their perception. 
* **Mind Reading:** "Basically i’m worried that if I see him in real life I will lash out at him." This implies the individual is assuming their former friend will provoke them, without any evidence.

**It's crucial to note:** These thoughts are serious and potentially dangerous. The individual needs professional help to address these distortions and develop healthy coping mechanisms.

Prompt: My life is currently a disaster. I understand other people have it worse. Physically, I am blessed. I have a roof over my head, food to eat, transportation, a supportive family, an amazing church, and a helpful therapist (who is both a mental health counselor as well as a drug and alcohol counselor) who truly seems to care. During a very recent hospitalization, I also began utilizing a journal to get my thoughts out in a private manner. I have an incredible support system I rarely utilize. I am struggling with a number of issues. I suck at reaching out before making terrible decisions such as self harm and drug use. I am an alcoholic and a drug addict who attends AA meetings regularly but have yet to pick up my 24-hour chip. I feel as if I’m not ready to surrender and work a program. I am, however, terrified of the consequences of alcoholism/drug use. Another fellowship I was previously a member of states these consequences at the start of every meeting: jails, institutions, and death. I lost one of my best friends in March to addiction. I have also seen many others lose their lives. While heroin is not my DOC, I feel as though any substance I choose to use will inevitably lead to some kind of consequence. I am in such a conundrum. That is the only word I can think of to describe this mess known as my life. Following the worst inpatient experience of my life, I am also struggling with the emotional pain of being on a very small amount of numerous medications. I am on the starting doses of these meds which have not nearly reached a therapeutic level. I feel as though I am mentally and emotionally unstable, as is proven by my recent words and actions towards others. This has caused others pull away, possibly permanently. I owe amends I’m not ready to give. As a member of AA, I believe in the ninth step. That is a step I struggled with a lot, though. There were a lot of repeated amends by mouth, but no changed behavior. It was unintentional lip service. I was and still am unsure of how to change my behavior. My next issue has to do with the job I just lost on Monday and the rest of the issues I haven’t discussed that were a result of this volcano that has just erupted. A few weeks ago, I put my two weeks notice in at a job I had worked at for three weeks shy of a year. I was burned out on working with the general public, so going back is not an option. I had just been offered a contracted cleaning job. So for my last two weeks of work at my old job, I worked both jobs. This was not a good decision. I was simultaneously feeling suicidal due to just being put on Latuda. I could not get ahold of my psychiatrist, so after just two weeks of working a brand new job, i found it necessary to go inpatient before I made a fatal decision. Following being inpatient, they told me at my new job that while I had been out of work for two weeks, they had to fill my position. I burned bridges, lost my sponsor as a result of using the day they let me go, and cut myself for the first time in two years. I feel too unstable to try to obtain and maintain employment at this time. I will not be able to pass a drug test at the moment. Not having a job leaves me with a ton of time on my hands. I am torn between applying for SSI and SSD and looking for a new job (in a few weeks.) This leaves me with no income. I am blessed to live with a parent who provides for me. I don’t really understand the point of sharing all of this. I am the one who needs to make some changes and decisions.
Response:
This anecdote demonstrates several cognitive distortions:

* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** "I suck at reaching out before making terrible decisions such as self harm and drug use." This statement frames the individual's struggles in absolute terms, implying they are incapable of seeking help before resorting to harmful behaviors. 
* **Should Statements:**  "I am not ready to surrender and work a program." This reflects an expectation that they "should" be ready for recovery at a specific point, which can lead to self-criticism and feelings of inadequacy.
* **Emotional Reasoning:** "I feel as though I am mentally and emotionally unstable, as is proven by my recent words and actions towards others." The individual uses their emotional state as evidence of instability, rather than considering other factors that might be contributing.
* **Mental Filter:**  The anecdote focuses heavily on negative aspects (job loss, self-harm, strained relationships) while downplaying positive elements like supportive family and therapy.
* **Magnification:** "I feel as though any substance I choose to use will inevitably lead to some kind of consequence." This exaggerates the potential consequences of drug use, leading to increased fear and anxiety.
* **Personalization:**  "This has caused others pull away, possibly permanently. I owe amends I’m not ready to give." The individual takes full responsibility for the actions of others (pulling away) and feels burdened by the need to make amends even when they are not emotionally prepared.

**Overall:** This anecdote reveals a pattern of negative thinking that contributes to the individual's distress. Addressing these cognitive distortions through therapy and self-reflection could be crucial in supporting their recovery journey.

Prompt: I have problems expressing my thoughts: Ever since the day I was born, I’ve always had problems expressing my thoughts and getting out what I wanted to say. Prompt: Hi, I took multiple online test for anxiety, depression, and bipolar. The anxiety came out extremely high, and I already know I have crazy anxiety issues. This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

The individual is basing their belief about having severe anxiety solely on the test results and a pre-existing feeling. They are not considering other factors or seeking professional confirmation.
* **Fortune-telling:** "I am scared if I tell him about it, he will think I am crazy." The individual is predicting a negative outcome without any concrete evidence. 
* **Mind Reading:**  "He just thought I was being silly." The individual assumes they know their father's thoughts and feelings without direct communication.

* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** "Currently, I have been just cutting my thighs up..." This indicates a potential struggle with seeing self-harm as the only solution to cope with overwhelming emotions.


**It is crucial to note:** The individual expresses suicidal thoughts. This requires immediate attention and professional help.  

**Recommendation:** Encourage the individual to reach out for help despite their fears. 

* **Crisis Hotlines:** Provide numbers for suicide prevention hotlines or crisis text lines.
* **Online Resources:** Share links to reputable mental health organizations that offer support and information.
* **Emphasize Safety:** Remind them that they are not alone and there are people who want to help. Their safety is the top priority.

Prompt: Yesterday my mother was admitted into the hospital for what is apparently a severe case of depression. My mother is 49 years old and she had a minor heart attack about 4 months ago. About two weeks after that she had to have a hysterecomy. She was fine after that. All of a sudden for the past few days she’s been doing things that aren’t her. She’s been hiding my step father’s clothing under the bed and following him everywhere he goes whether it’s to the bathroom, to the kitchen, etc.. She calls my sister and tells her that there are weird things going on in the house. She says that my step father stole her car, when he’s been driving her car for the past year and she’s been driving the new car. She says he’s trying to erase her family’s numbers from her cell phone. My sister took her to the hospital where she was admitted. She has since deteriorated in her condition. She doesn’t recognize her own mother any more, when I call her she talks to me as if I’m a stranger. When my 1 year old neice who my mother is crazy about went to the hospital to visit her, mother just kept pushing her away. She kept asking what the plastic bag(that the hospital gives you to put your clothing in) in her room was for. She then thought that the same plastic bag was a gift for her. We just found out that she quit her job of 6 years last Thursday without letting anyone know. She won’t sleep, eat, or take the meds that the hospital is giving her so they are now going to transfer her to a mental facility. Please help my understand what is happening. This is not my mother and I am so confused. Is my mother going to stay this way? Please respond.
Response:
This anecdote demonstrates several cognitive distortions, particularly in the context of the speaker's distress and confusion about their mother's sudden change in behavior. Here are some labels that apply:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** The speaker states "This is not my mother and I am so confused." This reflects a strong emotional reaction ("This is not my mother") leading to a conclusion without considering potential medical explanations for the drastic behavioral changes.
* **Fortune-telling:** The question "Is my mother going to stay this way?" reveals a prediction of a future outcome (permanent change) based on limited information and fear, rather than factual evidence.
* **Mind Reading:**  There's an assumption that the mother is acting intentionally and irrationally ("She’s been doing things that aren’t her," "She says..."). While the behavior is unusual, attributing it solely to conscious choices without understanding the underlying medical condition is a form of mind reading.
* **Magnification:** The speaker emphasizes the severity and strangeness of the mother's actions ("hiding clothing," "following everywhere," "doesn't recognize her own mother"), potentially exaggerating the impact and permanence of these changes.

**Important Note:** It's crucial to remember that these cognitive distortions are understandable given the stressful and confusing situation. The speaker is grappling with a loved one's sudden and drastic change in behavior, which naturally evokes strong emotions and fear.  


It's important for the speaker to seek support from mental health professionals who can help them understand their mother's condition and cope with the emotional turmoil.

Prompt: So basically my entire childhood has been deeply traumatic. Since I was 6, I lived with my abusive mother (my parents are divorced). I’ve been chronically depressed for as long as I can remember and I have been spiritually interactive as you could say. From age 7, I could see demons in my waking and sleeping hours (Not to mention I had two childhood friends witch happened to be very terrifying demons that have haunted me for basically my entire life). I have had countless interactions with demons and angels. I have attempted suicide 4 times now. Some of the time I sort of laps into a insane mood when I am alone (about once every week or two) witch is full of uncontrollable shaking, self harm, very sadistic and psychotic thinking patterns, uncontrollable crying, rage and basic psychotic disorder symptoms. I am constantly paranoid and I suffer from severe depression, anxiety, insomnia and compulsive self hate. Keep in mind that I am currently 13. I have received little to no help with my mental problems and have a horrible habit of shoving everything down and hiding what I really feel (therefore my emotions are excessively raw and can overwhelm me at the slightest probing from my mother or basically anyone). I 100% consider myself to be unstable, but I am not sure about insane. Do you think I have Schizophrenia or Psychoses? Thanks for your time!
Response:
This anecdote exhibits several cognitive distortions that are commonly associated with mental health struggles. It's important to remember that **I am not a medical professional and cannot provide diagnoses.** However, based on the information provided, here are some potential labels:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "I feel this way, so it must be true" - The individual states they "100% consider myself to be unstable" based on their feelings. This aligns with emotional reasoning where feelings dictate truth rather than objective evaluation.
* **Overgeneralization:** Drawing sweeping negative conclusions with limited instances -  Statements like "my entire childhood has been deeply traumatic" and "I have been chronically depressed for as long as I can remember" suggest broad, negative conclusions based on personal experiences. 
* **Mental Filter:** Focusing only on limited negative aspects and not the excessive positive ones - The anecdote heavily focuses on trauma, negative experiences with demons, suicidal thoughts, and mental health struggles. It doesn't mention any potential positive coping mechanisms or supportive relationships.
* **Should Statements:** Expecting things or personal behavior should be a certain way - Phrases like "I should be stable" imply an expectation of how they *should* feel rather than accepting their current emotional state.
* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** Binary thought pattern. Considering anything short of perfection as a failure - The individual labels themselves as "unstable" and questions whether they are "insane," suggesting a black-and-white thinking pattern where there is no middle ground.
* **Magnification:** Exaggerating or Catastrophizing the outcome of certain events or behavior -  Describing experiences with demons, suicidal attempts, and intense emotional episodes suggests a potential tendency to magnify the severity of situations.

**It's crucial for this individual to seek professional help from a mental health provider.** They are experiencing significant distress and their symptoms warrant thorough evaluation and appropriate treatment.

Prompt: My father has always had issues with drugs, drinking, and anger issues. All three together are just toxic. * **Should Statements:** There are implied "should" statements like "He should be taking his medication" and "He shouldn't be cheating on my mother." These reflect expectations about how the father should behave rather than accepting his current reality.



It's important to remember that these are just potential interpretations based on the limited information provided. A full understanding of the situation would require more context and insight into the individual's thoughts and feelings.

Prompt: Hello, So I’m 15 and under medication for (suicidal)depression (I take clomipramine). I have dealt with self harm and such issues and my depression is under control. This anecdote exhibits several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** The statement "I feel angry and hateful, so it must be true" exemplifies emotional reasoning. Feelings are being accepted as factual evidence rather than being recognized as temporary states influenced by various factors.

* **Magnification:** Fantasizing about hurting or killing people, while stating they would never act on these thoughts, demonstrates magnification. The individual is exaggerating the potential consequences of their anger and fear.
* **Mental Filter:** Focusing solely on the negative feelings (anger, hate) and ignoring any positive aspects of themselves ("one kind person")  illustrates a mental filter.

It's important to note that this individual is already under medication for depression and suicidal ideation. These distortions could be symptoms of their underlying condition and should be discussed with their healthcare provider.
