Prompt: Well it all really started when I came out to my parents. I thought it would be okay even though I knew they didn’t agree with that lifestyle but I didn’t know just how much they thought it was wrong. Before I came out to them they were easy going and even though my mom yelled a lot we all seemed to get along well enough. I had a blog, was on lots of different social media sites and talked to all kinds of people. After I came out my parents immediately started having “talks” with me. They put me down, told me to not live that lifestyle and that I would never be happy. I listened even though I didn’t agree. Eventually after a few weeks of this my parents sat me down and told me they had been through all my social media, including the private ones, my friends accounts (which were also private but my mom majored in computers and was able to get into them) and eventually they found out through these sites that I liked my best friend and she liked me. To a lot of our close friends we were dating, me and this girl but I had kept it secret from my parents knowing they wouldn’t approve. Me and my girlfriend had only ever kissed twice at this point and hadn’t gone far at all but my parents completely freaked out. They made me delete all my social media, break up with my girlfriend and they took all my electronics, including a simple tablet I used for drawing. They told me which friends I could keep and deleted anyone else who they didn’t like (for any little reason) out of my contacts. I wasn’t allowed to talk to people for weeks and I wasn’t allowed to hang out with anyone almost at all. I’ve gone to them many times and told them they are being too controlling and I even broke down during one of our “talks” and told them I’ve been depressed and self harming a little but they haven’t seemed to care. All they’ve cared about is that I’m nowhere near that “alternative lifestyle.” Sorry this probably is a pretty dumb problem but it’s making me depressed and hate them. Any way I can get them to calm down?
Response:
This anecdote exhibits several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:**  "I've gone to them many times and told them they are being too controlling...but they haven’t seemed to care. All they’ve cared about is that I’m nowhere near that “alternative lifestyle.” " The narrator feels their parents don't care, therefore concluding it must be true without considering other perspectives.

* **Overgeneralization:**  "They made me delete all my social media, break up with my girlfriend and they took all my electronics...I wasn’t allowed to talk to people for weeks and I wasn’t allowed to hang out with anyone almost at all." This experience is generalized into a belief that their parents will *always* be controlling and prevent them from having any social life.

* **Mental Filter:** The narrator focuses solely on the negative aspects of their parents' behavior (control, disapproval) while ignoring any potential positive aspects they might have.

* **Should Statements:**  "I even broke down during one of our “talks” and told them I’ve been depressed and self harming a little but they haven’t seemed to care." The narrator implies their parents *should* care about their mental health, highlighting a rigid expectation.

* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** "Me and my girlfriend had only ever kissed twice at this point and hadn’t gone far at all but my parents completely freaked out."  The narrator sees their relationship as insignificant (only kissing twice) while their parents react as if it's a major transgression, leading to an all-or-nothing perspective on the situation.

* **Mind Reading:** "To a lot of our close friends we were dating, me and this girl but I had kept it secret from my parents knowing they wouldn’t approve." The narrator assumes their parents wouldn't approve without directly communicating with them about it.


It's important to note that these are just labels for patterns of thinking. They don't define the narrator as a person, and recognizing these distortions can be a first step towards challenging them and developing healthier coping mechanisms.

Prompt: I am a shy person by nature, I generally dislike and don’t care to be social. But in this past year I’ve gone further than that, rather what I would call paranoid tendencies. Even so much that I’m afraid to tell people my name, how old I am, and similar information, so I often end up lying. When I say something truthful I want to punch myself.
Response:
The label that best fits this anecdote is **Mind Reading**. 

Here's why:

* **Assumption without Evidence:** The individual states they are afraid to tell people basic information about themselves and resorts to lying. This suggests a belief that others will react negatively to their true identity, age, etc., *without any factual basis*.  
* **Paranoid Tendencies:** The mention of "paranoid tendencies" further supports this label. Mind reading often accompanies paranoia as individuals assume negative intentions or judgments from others.

While there might be elements of other cognitive distortions present (like **Should Statements** - "I *should* be able to tell people my name"), the core issue presented is the assumption of how others will react without any evidence.

Prompt: I am a 30 (one child, once divorced) year old woman, have been seeing a 42 year old man (never married no kids) for about 5 months. For the most part our relationship is good, but he won’t stop bringing up my sexual past and asking seriously intrusive questions. He wants to know every single personal detail and exact numbers, all the way back to high school! I’ve told him Im uncomfortable talking about it and I think its unhealthy, since it is irrelevant now, but he just gets angry and emotional. He has some perfectionism issues and claims that he’s avoided one night stands his whole life in order to be the “perfect” partner to someone someday and wishes i would’ve done the same. He says this is my punishment, having to admit the things I’ve done and be ashamed. Im so confused I don’t know how to handle these inquisitions every month. or so. Im ready to leave if this doesn’t stop but I wish I knew how to make this stop. Or SHOULD I feel guilty for my past?! HELP PLEASE!
Response:
This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Should Statements:** "SHOULD I feel guilty for my past?!" The individual is questioning whether they *should* feel a certain way, indicating an internalized set of rules about how they "should" behave.

* **Emotional Reasoning:**  He "gets angry and emotional," implying that his feelings are dictating the situation's truth. His anger is being used to justify his intrusive behavior.
* **Mental Filter:** The individual focuses solely on her partner's negative behavior (the inquiries) while seemingly downplaying the positive aspects of their relationship ("For the most part our relationship is good").

* **Labeling:** He labels her experiences as "punishment" and implies she should be "ashamed." This attempts to assign negative labels to her past actions.
* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** His statement about avoiding one-night stands his whole life to be the "perfect" partner suggests a black-and-white view of relationships and sexual history.

**It's important to note:**  The individual is also experiencing distress and questioning her own feelings, which are valid reactions to this situation.

Prompt: I noticed that I tend to avoid eye contact with others whether they are good friends of mine or a family member. I try to but always feel my eyes wet and irritated. Most of the times I can’t hold a normal conversation (I talk to others but not as much as I’d like to) and feel that I’m lacking concentration or don’t give enough attention to others and what they are telling me. On the other hand I often wake up feeling down(sad) and actually don’t want to communicate with anyone else. I used to think I’m just a shy person but I realised it could be something more. I’m 19 so shouldn’t it be like a second nature to me?

The anecdote you provided suggests several cognitive distortions at play:

* **Should Statements:** "I'm 19 so shouldn't it be like a second nature to me?" This statement implies an expectation that social interaction should be effortless by this age, setting up unrealistic standards.
* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:**  The writer expresses difficulty holding normal conversations and feeling like they don't give enough attention. This could reflect an all-or-nothing thought pattern where anything less than perfect social engagement is perceived as a failure. 
* **Mental Filter:** The anecdote focuses heavily on the negative aspects of social interaction (avoiding eye contact, feeling down, lack of concentration) while potentially overlooking any positive interactions or moments of connection.

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "I often wake up feeling down (sad) and actually don’t want to communicate with anyone else." Feeling sad leads to a conclusion about not wanting to communicate. This links emotions directly to assumed truths without considering other factors.
 


It's important to remember that these are just possible interpretations based on the limited information provided. A mental health professional would be better equipped to make a more accurate assessment.

Prompt: A loved one is suffering from mutism since experiencing a traumatic event. She is not talking at all. Not to family. Not to anyone. I have been looking online and it seems selective mutism is an anxiety problem. She is also listless, does not engage in activities that she normally has before this, does not eat or sleep well, and seems distressed when she has to leave the house or be without the company of a family member. What is the best course of action to getting her back to her old self and over this issue? I think therapy might help but not if she is not talking. I also do not want to make her talk if she is not ready to talk but this is not normal. Thanks for your time.
Response:
The primary cognitive distortion present in this anecdote is **All-or-Nothing Thinking**.  

Here's why:

* **"This is not normal"** reflects a black-and-white, all-or-nothing thought pattern. The individual is struggling to accept the complexity of their loved one's situation and viewing it solely as "abnormal" or "wrong." Should I be held to the standard of faith persevering through childhood regardless of my situational experiences that may have influenced me/made me sour? Probably. May this post-isolation, asocial behavior, and cognitive deceleration be overcome? My optimism says that with genuine help and love from another/few who is/are unpaid and not eager to jump to diagnoses while also being invested in my growth, it can and will be. My pessimism speaks on the idea that this pragmatism is often used to manipulate and regress.
Response:
This anecdote exhibits several cognitive distortions:

* **Should Statements:** "Should I be held to the standard of faith persevering through childhood regardless..." This phrase indicates the individual is applying a rigid "should" statement about how they believe they *should* have behaved in the past.
* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** "...cognitive deceleration be overcome? My optimism says... My pessimism speaks on the idea that this pragmatism is often used to manipulate and regress." This demonstrates a tendency towards black-and-white thinking, with no room for nuance or middle ground.  Either they will fully overcome their issues with help, or they will be manipulated and regress.
* **Emotional Reasoning:** "hypothetically considering punishment to come in the afterlife (though never later in life, which was the largest sort of “karmic” disregard)." The individual seems to be basing their beliefs about deserving punishment on feelings rather than objective evidence. 

**Possible Additional Distortions:**

* **Personalization:**  The anecdote suggests a strong sense of personal responsibility for past actions and potential future consequences ("underlying issues committed in childhood").
* **Labeling:** Phrases like "negligent atheism" and "cognitive deceleration" could be examples of labeling themselves negatively.



It's important to remember that identifying cognitive distortions is the first step towards addressing them. With self-awareness and possibly professional guidance, the individual can learn to challenge these distorted thought patterns and develop more balanced and realistic perspectives.

* **Mind Reading:**  "They’re both going out partying every weekend, going to concerts like they’re both still in high school." This suggests she's assuming their motivations and intentions without direct knowledge.

It's important to note that these are just potential interpretations based on a brief anecdote. A professional therapist could provide a more nuanced and accurate assessment.

Prompt: I am in a relationship with a 49 yoa male who has not had a lasting relationship in 19 years. He is a realist, recovering alcohol of 25 yrs, does not believe in Western Medicine and speaks the truth about everything regardless of feelings. We have had challenges from day one but the most recent challenge is that he has enacted stipulations that we will not attend public events together, we will not eat at restaurants together, we will not attend a movie together, etc – all because he believes I am unable to control my behavior/emotions. For example, we attended an event in which I ran into a male who had caused a serious injury to myself in which I almost lost a leg. I have not seen this male since the final court date.The male dragged out things out for years causing me more money and frustration to collect on his criminal restitution. Yes, I was surprised to see him at the event, told my bf who the male was and expressed disgust of seeing him again. I did not approach the male or speak to him. The whole incident/my behavior last possibly 5 mins before I collected myself and went back to having a good time. Since that event, my bf believes I have anger issues and can not be trusted to “stay in the moment” with him therefore he will not attend any more events with me because he “will not put himself” in that situation again. Nothing I did or said should have affected my bf therefore I am confused to say the least. He explained it as why should he feel uncomfortable or give support to me for something I should have dealt with already. He does not want to go to the movies because I once mentioned I was uncomfortable in the seats however we have since gone to two movies with the new seating and I have been fine. He knows that but for some reason has decided all of sudden to issue this stipulation. I believe this is controlling manipulative behavior, possibly passive aggressive and punishment for things I may have done or said that he will not forgive me for. I do not believe this is normal but he has me almost convinced I am at fault for these stipulations. Please help me understand what is going on. (From the USA)
Response:
This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Mind Reading:** The boyfriend assumes his girlfriend has anger issues and can't be trusted based solely on her reaction to seeing someone who caused her harm. He doesn't ask her how she feels or tries to understand her perspective.
* **Should Statements:**  He believes she "should have dealt with" the past incident already, implying there's a right way to feel and react to trauma.
* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** He applies a blanket rule (no public events) based on one isolated incident. 
* **Mental Filter:** He focuses solely on the negative aspect of her reaction (potential anger) while ignoring the fact that she didn't confront the man, controlled her emotions quickly, and continued enjoying herself.
* **Personalization:** He blames himself for feeling uncomfortable in situations with his girlfriend, suggesting he is responsible for her actions and reactions.
* **Emotional Reasoning:** His belief that she can't be trusted stems from his feelings of discomfort rather than any concrete evidence of her behavior.

**Possible Additional Factors:**


* **Control Issues:** The boyfriend may be exhibiting controlling behavior by limiting their social activities together. This could stem from insecurity, fear, or a need to exert dominance in the relationship.
* **Projection:** He might be projecting his own unresolved anger or fear onto his girlfriend.

It's important for the girlfriend to recognize these distortions and communicate her feelings assertively. She may also want to consider whether this relationship is truly healthy and supportive for her.

I feel bad about my fiancé how I talk to her but my mind just nonstop thinking crazy stuff:( I’m really at my end with what to do. She love of my life but I feel I should make her leave me so I don’t ruin her life. I’m really scared :(
Response:
This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Mind Reading:** "They were looking at me weird like they can tell I’m off and weird."  He assumes others are judging him negatively without any concrete evidence.
* **Emotional Reasoning:** "I feel bad how I am towards her but I can’t stop I don’t know why." He lets his feelings of inadequacy dictate his actions, rather than rationally addressing the issue.
* **Overgeneralization:**  "I have always been off socially... I can’t seem to be around anyone I feel like they out to get me." He generalizes a few negative social experiences into a belief that everyone is against him.
* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** "I’m not good in bed and I think this makes me really insecure."  He sees his sexual performance as black and white, leading to intense insecurity.
* **Personalization:** "I feel like all my friends want my girlfriend like they only around to get her." He takes responsibility for the actions and desires of others, believing they are motivated solely by wanting his fiancée.
* **Magnification:** "Last night I went out with my fiancé and she left me with her friends and I just couldn’t think on one thing to say...She went to bathroom seems like she was gone so long I had a panic attack and left bar and walked 6 hours home." He catastrophizes a normal social situation, turning it into a major crisis.
* **Should Statements:** "I feel bad about my fiancé how I talk to her but my mind just nonstop thinking crazy stuff:( I’m really at my end with what to do. She love of my life but I feel I should make her leave me so I don’t ruin her life." He feels he *should* be able to control his thoughts and actions, leading to guilt and self-deprecation.

**It's important to note:** This anecdote suggests a serious struggle with mental health.  The individual is experiencing significant distress and may benefit greatly from professional help.

Prompt: From a teen in the U.S.: So here is my situation: I have anxiety for quite a few situations. It is not ONLY social situations or for a specific phobia. I sometimes just worry about being pitied or thought about in any sense, as I stick out as waiting, and sometimes I worry that my dad has gotten into an accident or something and I get really anxious j) driving. everything about it. I cant. k) the thought of making new friends/dating
Response:
This anecdote exhibits several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "It is not ONLY social situations...I have the typical anxiety symptoms (though mild in comparison to those who throw up, have panic attacks, etc)"  The teen compares their anxiety to others and dismisses it as "mild," likely minimizing their own feelings.
* **Overgeneralization:** "when I feel like a nuisance for employees at restaurants (my family is being slow, etc)" This single instance of feeling like a nuisance is generalized into a broader belief about themselves.
* **Should Statements:** "everyone around me leaves on their own terms" This implies the teen *should* be able to leave on their own terms, leading to anxiety when they can't.
* **Mind Reading:**  "...and I sometimes just worry about being pitied or thought about in any sense..." The teen assumes others are pitying them without concrete evidence.
* **Fortune-telling:** "...sometimes I worry that my dad has gotten into an accident or something and I get really anxious" This predicts the worst possible outcome (an accident) based on limited information.
* **Magnification:**  "everything about it. I cant." The teen exaggerates the difficulty of driving, making it seem insurmountable.


**Additional Notes:**

It's important to remember that experiencing some anxiety is normal. However, the frequency and intensity of this teen's anxieties suggest they may benefit from exploring coping mechanisms or seeking professional help.

Prompt: From a teen in the U.S.: i”ve been dealing with depression and anxiety issues since i was 6 years old. i’ve never really enjoyed living, being so depressed makes me push away everyone i care about, leaves me unmotivated quitting every job ive had and dropping out of high school, and constantly wanting to be alone and curl up in a ball and not do anything with my life. i have no energy and i kinda just sit and sulk all day, i also deal with bipolar, extremely bad panic attacks multiple times a day, and body dysmorphia.

It's important to remember that these are just potential labels based on the limited information provided. A proper diagnosis and understanding of the teen's situation would require a comprehensive evaluation by a mental health professional.

Prompt: Inside of this fleshy prison live the three of us: Harry, George, and me. Normally, we get along perfectly, each respecting one another’s problems, such as George’s ‘depression’ and Harry’s ‘schizophrenia’ (both of which have not been diagnosed or discussed with a professional). Unlike the other two, I seemingly lack a few emotions, such as grief, remorse, and empathy. Normally, this is more of a strength than a weakness, but as of late, it has been rather difficult to deal with. It’s perfectly normal for me to experience urges to kill living creatures or to break inanimate objects, and these urges are understood by Harry and George. However, with each passing day these urges seem to grow stronger, and Harry and George seem to grow more…’on edge’. When we discuss the subject, the others seem to react with more fear, or aggression, than they used to, and they don’t seem to understand my situation as well as they used to. Previously, I could control my urges perfectly. I fidget a lot, which used to calm the urges, and I can also be quite destructive if I want something (I chewed through a television remote so that I could play with the rubber buttons inside), which also helped. Leaving windows open and then killing the insects that entered the house was another good way to calm myself. However, none of these methods seem to do much good anymore. I want something more, something bigger. Hunting is out of the question for me – there isn’t anywhere to go in my local area and if I ask an adult it will arouse suspicion (they all believe that Harry, George, and myself are a singular, ‘normal’ entity). With each day these urges growing stronger, I also grow more impatient and frustrated with tiny details. Things – and people – are bothering me more and more, and this is encouraging my fantasies of killing them. There’s only two people I would never be able to kill, and they’re not a part of my family, which means I have to control myself greatly each day around the people I’m supposed to ‘love’. With all of that said, it brings me onto my questions. What can I do to calm my desire to kill? And, lastly, is calming my urges that only way to make Harry and George feel comfortable with me again? Thanks.
Response:
This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** The narrator believes their urge to kill is justified because they "feel" it. They don't question the morality or rationality of these urges.
* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:**  The narrator sees hunting as the only solution to their urges, dismissing other possibilities. This binary thinking ("hunt or nothing") limits their problem-solving abilities.
* **Mind Reading:** The narrator assumes Harry and George are "on edge" and react with fear or aggression because they don't understand the situation. They project their own feelings onto others without confirmation. 
* **Magnification:** The narrator exaggerates the severity of their urges and the negative impact on their relationships. Phrases like "growing stronger" and "fantasies of killing them" heighten the perceived danger.
* **Labeling:** The narrator labels themselves as lacking emotions, which could be a form of self-deprecation or a way to justify their violent thoughts.

**It's crucial to remember that this is just an analysis based on a fictional anecdote.** It's not meant to diagnose or label the narrator in any real sense.  The story raises important questions about mental health and the dangers of unchecked impulses.

Prompt: I have had panic attacks for 10 years recently they have gotten so much worse and I can’t get through them anymore. My heart has been checked I’ve had a monitor for a month, stress echo, ekgs all they have found is premature beats but I’m still convinced and its ruining my life. Now I can’t tell if my heart is racing first or I am having anxiety then it starts racing. I’ve been trying to get into a mental dr but haven’t been able to. Please any advice on what I should do I can’t stop obsessing i check my pulse over and over and If it goes up at all I freak out I’m living in misery.
Response:
This anecdote demonstrates several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "My heart will go fast for no reason... so now I'm convinced I have A fib and I can't let it go." The individual is interpreting their physical sensation (a racing heart) as evidence of a serious medical condition, despite medical tests showing otherwise.
* **Overgeneralization:**  "All they have found is premature beats but I'm still convinced..." This statement suggests the individual is drawing a sweeping conclusion about having A-fib based on limited evidence and dismissing the results of multiple tests.
* **Mental Filter:** The anecdote focuses solely on the negative aspects (racing heart, anxiety) and ignores any positive aspects, such as the fact that they have undergone extensive medical testing to rule out serious conditions.
* **Catastrophizing/Magnification:** "If it goes up at all I freak out I'm living in misery." The individual is exaggerating the impact of their racing heart, suggesting it's causing unbearable suffering and ruining their life.
* **Fortune-telling:**  "Now I can’t tell if my heart is racing first or I am having anxiety then it starts racing." This statement reflects a prediction that anxiety will always lead to a racing heart, creating a self-fulfilling prophecy.

**It's important to note:**  This individual is clearly experiencing significant distress and would benefit from professional help. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) can be particularly effective in addressing these types of cognitive distortions and developing healthier coping mechanisms.

Prompt: So I met my best friends in the world when I started college. I finally found a group of people I clicked with and it was all great last year. Response:
The primary cognitive distortion present in this anecdote is **Mind Reading**.  

Here's why:

* **Assumption without evidence:** The individual assumes their friends "switched on" them and that their best friend "hates" them. There's no direct communication or confirmation of these feelings from the friends themselves.
* **Interpreting actions as malicious:** Ignoring someone can have various reasons unrelated to hatred (being busy, preoccupied, etc.). Jumping to the conclusion of malice without seeking clarification is characteristic of mind reading.


While other distortions might be subtly present (like **Emotional Reasoning** - feeling hurt leading them to believe they're hated), **Mind Reading** is the most prominent and driving force behind their interpretation of the situation.

It's important to note:

* **Professional Diagnosis:**  Only a qualified mental health professional can accurately diagnose and assess cognitive distortions.

It's important to note that diagnosing someone based on anecdotal evidence is impossible and unethical.  However, recognizing these cognitive distortions can help the writer understand their own thought patterns and potentially approach the situation with more clarity and compassion.

I’ve lost friends because they want me to tell them whats wrong but I just can’t. I’m scared they will tell the administration. Who will then tell my mom. I only cut on my thighs now because if they are on my arms, people will see them. And that would give me more anxiety, which would make me cut more. It’s a vicious path I would rather not go down. I’m already addicted to cutting, and it’s really, really hard to stop. I know I can, I just don’t know how. Please help me.

This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "The longer I cut, the deeper the cut has to be for me to feel any sense of relief." This demonstrates believing that the feeling (need for relief) justifies the action (deeper cuts).
* **Should Statements:**  "I think she will tell my mom" and "I don’t want her to think I’m more of a disgrace than I already am" suggest rigid expectations about how others should behave.

* **Mind Reading:** The individual assumes their mother will think they are a disgrace and that the doctor will definitely tell their mother, without any factual basis for these beliefs.
* **Fortune-telling:** "I know there are confidentiality laws but I think those only come into play when you’re not hurting yourself or others" predicts a negative outcome based on assumption rather than fact.
* **Magnification:** The fear of being judged and the perceived consequences (telling administration, telling mom) are exaggerated, leading to avoidance behaviors.

* **Personalization:** "I've lost friends because they want me to tell them what’s wrong but I just can’t" places blame on themselves for losing friends, when it could be due to other factors as well.
* **Labeling:** The individual labels themselves as a "disgrace," which contributes to negative self-image and reinforces the cycle of self-harm.



It's important to note that this is a serious situation requiring professional help. This analysis is for informational purposes only and should not be interpreted as medical advice.

Prompt: I have had this problem for the majority of life where it began with a suicidal depression at the age of 9. I no longer have strong impulses to commit suicide, although these visual thoughts and impulses has changed into hurting or even killing others. I am a visual thinker, which I guess is why these thoughts seems so lifelike. These thoughts also come very sudden, and are related to the present situation I am in. I am right now in a relationship with my girlfriend and we have a child (2 years old) and two cats. I have had previous thoughts of harming my girlfriend, which is usual to me since I get these thoughts often towards other humans. On the other hand it started bothering me when I got very strong, visual impulses to hurt our infant child. I got real reason to worry since I have never been good to remember any dreams, but the last two or three I can remember involves harming or killing our daughter, which is very distressfull. Sometimes these impulses can be very hard to handle, which is the reason why I chose to register on this website. We got a new kitten the other day, and even that she is in a new location, she has adapted very well. But due to something as simple as her not wanting a cuddle drove both thoughts and action to treat her very aggressively and rough. Stopping myself from harming it, I had to sit alone in 15 minutes to calm myself down. Response:
This anecdote exhibits several cognitive distortions, making it crucial for this individual to seek professional help immediately. Here's a breakdown:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "I have these thoughts, so I must be capable of acting on them." This is a clear case of equating feelings with reality. Just because the thoughts are present doesn't mean they will translate into actions.
* **Mind Reading:** Assuming others (girlfriend, daughter) react negatively to him without any evidence.  
* **Fortune-Telling:** Predicting the worst possible outcome ("what can happen in the future towards my daughter?") without considering alternative possibilities or the individual's efforts to control these impulses.
* **Magnification:** Exaggerating the severity of the situation and the likelihood of acting on the harmful thoughts.

**Additional Concerns:**

* **History of Suicidal Depression:** This is a significant red flag and highlights the need for ongoing mental health support.
* **Visual Nature of Thoughts:** While visual thinking isn't inherently problematic, the vividness and content of these thoughts are concerning and require professional assessment.
* **Difficulty Controlling Impulses:**  The individual acknowledges struggling to control their impulses, even towards a kitten. This is a serious warning sign that needs immediate attention.

**It's crucial that this person seeks help from a mental health professional as soon as possible.** They need support in managing these thoughts, understanding the nature of cognitive distortions, and developing coping mechanisms to prevent harm to themselves or others.  



Remember, this is not a diagnosis but an analysis based on the provided information. Only a qualified professional can provide an accurate assessment and treatment plan.

Prompt: I didn’t realize I was suffering from depression until many years into it. I finally went to a psychologist and psychiatrist when my life was falling apart. I felt awful and had felt awful for a very long time, but after getting on medications and feeling like a normal, happy person for a couple years, it all felt like an old unreal dream. So I decided to stop my medications. My doctors advised me against it, saying that if I had suffered more than 3 episodes, I should stay on medication indefinitely, but I had never “counted” my episodes. Really, it just felt like I was born with one long and nasty episode. I have been off my meds for a month now and I feel horrible. My anxiety is so bad that my whole body hurts from being so tense and shaky. I’m missing work either because I’m too busy crying or I just don’t want to deal with life. I feel lonely, sad, and hopeless. I feel like I am cursed for life. From what I have read and heard, depression occurs in episodes. But I feel like I am doomed to feel like this forever, having no respite unless I take high doses of medications. Is it possible that I just have a “lifetime long episode”? I only went to see a psychiatrist when I was 22, about a year after I moved out of my parents house. My parents are deniers of mental illness – the have a “pick yourself up by your bootstraps” / “you can’t possibly have depression” attitudes, so I always attributed my poor mental status to a character flaw. But when I reflect on my childhood and adolescence, I don’t ever remember being happy. I think I was always depressed. I cannot possibly live my life feeling this depressed but I don’t want to take medication for the rest of my life either. I haven’t even mentioned that my medications and behavioral therapies have done absolutely nothing to help my OCD. That I have heard can last a lifetime. I don’t think I can live like this. It’s getting to be too much. It can all be tolerated until you realize that, for the rest of your existence, none of this will go away.
Response:
This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "I feel awful and have felt awful for a very long time... it just felt like I was born with one long and nasty episode." The individual is basing their understanding of their depression solely on how they feel, without considering other factors or perspectives.
* **Overgeneralization:**  "I feel like I am doomed to feel like this forever, having no respite unless I take high doses of medications." They are drawing a sweeping conclusion about their future based on limited experience and current feelings.
* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** "My medications and behavioral therapies have done absolutely nothing to help my OCD."  This statement reflects a black-and-white perspective, failing to acknowledge any potential benefits or nuances in the treatment's effectiveness.
* **Fortune-Telling:** "It can all be tolerated until you realize that, for the rest of your existence, none of this will go away." They are predicting a negative future outcome without concrete evidence.
* **Magnification:** "My anxiety is so bad that my whole body hurts from being so tense and shaky." The individual is exaggerating the physical symptoms of their anxiety.
* **Labeling:** "I feel like I am cursed for life." They are attaching a negative label to themselves, reinforcing feelings of hopelessness.


**Additionally:**

* There might be elements of **Should Statements** present ("I don't want to take medication for the rest of my life"), reflecting an expectation about how their treatment should proceed.
* The anecdote also hints at **Personalization**, as they blame themselves for their depression and attribute it to a "character flaw" due to their parents' dismissive attitude towards mental health. 

It's important to remember that these are just potential interpretations based on the provided text. A proper diagnosis can only be made by a qualified mental health professional.

Prompt: Hi there, I have a question regarding to my mom and why she appears to hate me in comparison to my brother and sister. I’m the oldest, my brother is the middle child and my sister is the youngest. My brother, my parents seemed to have focused majority of their attention on him which honestly wasn’t a big deal to me, but my sister who has caused so much grief on my mom even calling her the c-word and run in with the law and being physically violent with her still is treated with so much more respect than me. I’m not saying I’m perfect but I was a child of obedience, good grades, never swore, just desperately wanted to please my parents to no end, you get the picture. When I was a teenager she was physically and emotionally abusive with me, she went through a bad divorce with my dad and the death of her mother and sister so she did take it out on us, more so me and dealing with bulimia.  My mom does depend on me now for rides to work because she lost her license and does have type 1 diabetes so I’m the one responsible for her even though I want to move out and begin my life with my 7 year boyfriend. My mom doesn’t approve of us living together so I am afraid she will end our mother daughter relationship because she’s threatened it before. To this day she treats me horribly compared to my brother and sister even though I try hard not to start fights with her, I’m very quiet and passive which I guess she hates? And she walks all over me if my sister refuses to do something for my mom. Whenever I have tried to tell her how I feel she manipulates me into thinking something is wrong with me, she also seems to have a narcissistic personality problem but I’m not going to diagnose her. How can I begin my life without starting a war. An example that happened is that I expressed excitement over my future home that I offered that she can help decorate, she refused and said if I moved out she would never come over or talk to me but when my brother expressed wanting to move out she offered to pay his rent. Please help. (age 25, from Canada)
Response:
This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "My mom appears to hate me...she treats me horribly." The individual is basing their conclusion about their mother's feelings solely on her actions and treatment, rather than considering other possible explanations.
* **Overgeneralization:**  "To this day she treats me horribly...she walks all over me." Drawing broad conclusions ("horribly," "walks all over me") based on specific instances without acknowledging potential nuances or changes in the relationship dynamic.
* **Mental Filter:** Focusing only on the negative aspects of the relationship (her mother's mistreatment, lack of support) and overlooking any positive interactions or her mother's dependence on her for practical needs.
* **Should Statements:** "I’m not saying I’m perfect but I was a child of obedience...desperately wanted to please my parents."  Implying that she *should* have been rewarded for good behavior and that her mother's actions are unfair given her past efforts.

* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** "Whenever I have tried to tell her how I feel she manipulates me into thinking something is wrong with me..." Viewing the situation as either complete success (her mother understanding and changing) or complete failure (manipulation and feeling invalidated).
* **Mind Reading:** "she’s threatened it before." Assuming her mother will end their relationship based on past threats without concrete evidence of her intentions.

* **Fortune-telling:** "I am afraid she will end our mother daughter relationship..." Predicting a negative outcome (estrangement) without considering other possibilities or attempting to communicate her needs constructively.



It's important for the individual to recognize these cognitive distortions and challenge them with more balanced and realistic thoughts. This could involve:

* **Seeking support:** Talking to a therapist or counselor can help her develop healthier coping mechanisms and communication strategies.
* **Setting boundaries:** Learning to say "no" and assert her needs respectfully, even if it means facing temporary conflict.
* **Focusing on self-care:** Prioritizing her own well-being through activities that bring her joy and fulfillment.

Remember, changing deeply ingrained patterns takes time and effort. Being patient with herself and celebrating small victories along the way is crucial.

* **Labeling:**  "arrogant and stuck up" are labels used by the father and potentially internalized by the writer, contributing to feelings of self-doubt and inadequacy. 



It's important to remember that cognitive distortions are common thought patterns that can be challenged and changed with awareness and practice. Recognizing these distortions is the first step towards developing healthier thinking patterns and coping mechanisms for dealing with difficult relationships.

Prompt: My fiance and I have been together for 4 years. About 3 months into our break we started going out on dates and working toward getting back to normal, but we were not officially together. I recently found out about the sex because he left his email logged on to my computer and he was emailing her an apology for his poor behavior with her. This is the first time he has been physical with another girl, but during other parts of our relationship I have caught him sexting his ex and at one point I found him texting one of his peers at school telling her that he didn’t get enough attention from me and he wanted to kiss her and see if she was the thing missing from his life. I don’t know how to proceed with him. I love him very much and our wedding is in 2 years but I’m not sure after all of this if it is even worth the work it will be to fix our relationship. So should we work it out or should throw in the towel?
Response:
This anecdote demonstrates several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "I love him very much"  indicates a strong emotional attachment, which is influencing her decision-making. She's feeling conflicted due to love and hurt, making it hard to think rationally about the situation.
* **Mind Reading:** She assumes he wants to be with other women based on his past actions ("he didn't get enough attention from me and he wanted to kiss her").  She doesn't know his true intentions or feelings towards her.
* **Overgeneralization:** One incident of sex with another woman and sexting are being generalized as a pattern of infidelity and disrespect, potentially overshadowing the positive aspects of their relationship. 
* **Should Statements:** "should we work it out or should throw in the towel?" This phrasing implies an expectation that there's a right answer, putting pressure on herself to make a decision based on external rules rather than her own needs and feelings.

**Additional Considerations:**


While these distortions are present, it's important to acknowledge the complexity of the situation:

* **Past Trauma:** Her history of sexual abuse makes her more vulnerable to feeling betrayed and unsafe in relationships.
* **Communication Issues:**  The fiance's lack of transparency about his past actions is a major issue.  Open and honest communication is crucial for building trust.

**Recommendation:**

It's important for her to seek professional guidance from a therapist or counselor. They can help her:

* Identify and challenge the cognitive distortions influencing her thinking.
* Process her feelings of hurt, betrayal, and anger in a healthy way.
* Develop effective communication strategies with her fiance.

Prompt: From Albania: I am a female student (age 19) currently studying economics. I study at a private university and it is the second year, the problem I am struggling with is concentration, lack of self confidence, depression, I hate everything that I do. I have spent too much money and spent everything to get in that university and still there isn’t one exam I have passed, I cant study, I feel dumb, unnecessary, unworthy of everything that I’ve got.
Response:
This anecdote exhibits several cognitive distortions:

* **Overgeneralization:** "I haven't passed one exam... I feel dumb, unnecessary, unworthy."  She's drawing a sweeping conclusion about her intelligence and worth based on not passing exams.
* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:** "Anything short of perfection is a failure."  Failing exams is being interpreted as complete failure rather than an opportunity to learn and improve.
* **Emotional Reasoning:** "I hate everything that I do" – This statement seems driven by her feelings of despair and frustration rather than objective reasoning. 
* **Magnification:** The feeling of being "dumb, unnecessary, unworthy" are exaggerated reactions to a difficult situation.

* **Mental Filter:** She is focusing solely on the negative (failing exams, lack of confidence) and not acknowledging any potential positives in her situation (e.g.,  she's pursuing higher education, she's resilient for continuing despite struggles).
* **Labeling:** Calling herself "dumb" and "unnecessary" are examples of attaching negative labels to herself.

**It's important to note:** This is a complex situation, and it's crucial to approach it with empathy.  Professional help could be beneficial for her to address these cognitive distortions and develop healthier coping mechanisms.

Prompt: From the U.S.: I’ve started dating someone recently and I’ve realized that we are fairly bad at it since we can’t really seem to get into very personal topics. We met through a mutual friend almost a year ago, starting chatting on social media a few months ago and texting. Next time we have the opportunity to talk, what questions should I ask or what should I talk about? How do we get into personal conversation and avoid or at least reduce irrelevant garbage? Thank you.
Response:
The primary cognitive distortion present in this anecdote is **Should Statements**.

Here's why:

* **Expectation of "Should":** The individual expresses a belief that deeper, more personal conversations "should" happen in face-to-face interactions. They also state they are now leaving it up to him to propose outings, implying he "should" take initiative.  These are examples of imposing rigid expectations on how the dating process "should" unfold.

Let's look at why other labels might not be as fitting:

I have ADD but was never diagnosed with anything else, im suspecting i had bipolar symptoms before(i slept 2-3 hours and was eccentric. then heavily depressed). and i believe people send me hidden messages in their speech, im an artist and i can emerse myself in a nonexistant world, like i dont belong here and that killing myself will lead me to that prettier world. i do self doubt or try to ignore my thoughts but theyre still there. i get violent and jittery impulses, think about killing and torturing people like its nothing, and i get all excited and giggly. I have a nagging thought process that criticises me and other people. I try to remain honest with myself and laugh off any form of betrayal or oversensitivity. I interpret things to the extreme, sometimes unrealistic but i cant help buying in to it. I believe my father wants to kill me and my mother, i believe my sister is jealous i get more time with my mom, and i hate being happy. Whenever i get happy i need to remind myself i dont deserve to feel that or that its all fake and none if it will last. I self harm. My grades are poor and I prepare to commit suicide within the next three years, or maybe next year, or before college. I dont want to hurt my mother just in case she really does love me. I believe everyone will leave me and have isolated myself. Everything makes me cry. Help.
Response:
This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions consistent with serious mental health concerns. Here's a breakdown:

* **Emotional Reasoning:** "I feel like I don't belong here, and that killing myself will lead me to a prettier world." The individual is basing their belief about the afterlife on their current emotional state rather than rational thought.
* **Overgeneralization:** "I believe my father wants to kill me and my mother... I believe my sister is jealous I get more time with my mom." These are sweeping negative conclusions drawn from limited or possibly misinterpreted experiences. 
* **Mental Filter:**  Focusing on the perceived negatives (hurtful memories, paranoid thoughts) while seemingly ignoring any positive aspects of her family relationships.
* **Should Statements:** "I need to remind myself I don't deserve to feel that or that it's all fake and none of it will last." This reflects a belief about how she *should* feel rather than accepting her emotions as they are.
* **All-or-Nothing Thinking:**  "Whenever I get happy, I need to remind myself I don't deserve to feel that or that it's all fake and none of it will last." Happiness is seen as either entirely deserved or completely undeserved, with no room for nuance.
* **Mind Reading:** "I believe my father wants to kill me..."  Assuming knowledge of her father's intentions without any factual basis.
* **Fortune-telling:** "I prepare to commit suicide within the next three years, or maybe next year, or before college." Predicting a specific and negative future outcome.
* **Magnification:** Believing suicidal thoughts are justified due to feeling like she doesn't belong and that a "prettier world" awaits her in death. This exaggerates the perceived benefits of suicide.

**Personalization** is also potentially at play, as the individual seems to take responsibility for her family dynamics ("my sister is jealous"). 

**Labeling:** While not explicitly stated, there's a potential tendency towards self-labeling with phrases like "I'm suspecting I had bipolar symptoms before" and describing herself as selfish and defensive.


**It's crucial to understand that this is not a diagnosis.** This anecdote points to significant distress and potentially serious mental health concerns requiring immediate professional attention. 

**Please encourage this individual to seek help from a mental health professional, crisis hotline, or trusted adult immediately.**

This anecdote displays several cognitive distortions:

* **Labeling:** The individual labels themselves as someone who sees "demons and blood" and experiences "horrible things." This contributes to a negative self-image.
* **Personalization:** They feel personally responsible for the reactions of others, even though those reactions may stem from fear and misinformation about schizophrenia ("it's not bad enough I see demons...no they have to make it so I can’t even tell them what’s going on").

* **Should Statements:** There's an implied "should" statement regarding how therapists should respond – they "should" believe the individual isn't a danger instead of automatically hospitalizing them.


It's important to note that these distortions are common in individuals struggling with mental health conditions, particularly those facing stigma and misunderstanding.  The individual's experience highlights the need for compassion, education, and better support systems for people living with schizophrenia.

This anecdote demonstrates several cognitive distortions:

* **Emotional Reasoning:**  "I don't know why I let things get so bad. I suffer from a serious case of laziness and inconsistency." The speaker is attributing their actions (lying) to feelings ("laziness," "inconsistency") without exploring the underlying reasons or complexities. 
* **Should Statements:** "I know I have the potential to do great things, but I still get involved in too much endeavors but I can’t produce results." This implies a belief that they *should* be able to achieve everything they set out to do, leading to self-criticism and shame.

* **Mental Filter:** The speaker focuses on their failures (lying, not graduating) while downplaying successes (creating the NGO, maintaining friendship).

**Other potential distortions:**

* **Magnification:**  The impact of the lie is magnified ("shock" to friends and family), potentially leading to excessive guilt and fear.
* **Fortune-telling:** The speaker may be predicting a negative future outcome based on their past actions ("I don't know how to extract myself from all this").



It's important for the speaker to recognize these distortions and work towards more balanced thinking patterns. A therapist can help them explore the underlying reasons for their behavior and develop healthier coping mechanisms.
